text: strong citrus hops aroma. red and hazy in color with huge foamy head with faint brown/red tint. taste is slightly more balanced towards hoppyness and has faint dark caramel and light roasted malts flavor at finish.

Bouteille de 500 ml achetée chez Killington Market (Killington, VT) au coût de 7,00$. Arôme: Odeur de caramel fruité et de pin. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée opaque. Présence dun large col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel fruité avec une pointe de céréales grillées et de pin. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement houblonné. (Rating #6907)

Smells of sweet malt honey and a hint of fig at the end. Soothing red color with large white head. Taste of honey bitters and slight hint or raisin or dried fruit. Med body with lovely carbonation. Nice brew like this being in its own category. Nice work

$7.29 bomber from Wine Warehouse. Pours cloudy reddish brown with a nice, soft frothy beige head. Lovely aroma of pine, dark fruits, passion fruit, citrus, melon. Flavor is outstanding. Fruity roasted and toasted malts, bread crumbs, passion fruit, pine, aftertaste of definite apricot. VERY well done.

Bottle thanks to Don. Pours a cloudy brown with medium frothy beige head that lasts. The aroma is strong citrus, pine, spruce. Medium mouth, nice bitter hop bite, pine, grapefruit, light caramel in finish, very nice.

Bottle. Moderate aromas roasted grain and caramel for the malt, moderate pine for the hops, light soap for the yeast, with wood and dark dried fruit in the background. Head is average size, frothy, beige with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is murky, muddy on the last pour, dark red. Flavor starts slightly sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is medium, oily with a lively carbonation. Undoubtedly the best Amber Ale Ive had.
Malty but still fairly light and pliable on the palate. Slightly bitter, but the real story is the simple dark fruit that comes from the malt.

Bottle at Novare Res Bier Cafe, Portland. Originally rated 20160221. Bottled 020216 so it is super fresh. Colour is deep slightly cloudy reddish copper with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Caramel, fruits, harshness, hops and malts. Very impressive. Definitely best beer of this style. Body is amazing.

Aroma: caramel, pine, floral hops, grass, grain and cereal malts. Appearance: hazy amber, small, off-white, creamy head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: pine, molasses, caramel, citrus fruits, grapefruit, bread. Overall: very hoppy Amber Ale, great aroma, immensely complex palate. Bottle at Eleven Madison Park, Manhattan.

Pours a hazy amber with thick white head. Has a strong aroma of hops, caramel, malts, and pine. Taste is a mix of caramel, fruit malts, citrus hops, pine and some fruits and grains. A dry and bitter malt aftertaste.

Perhaps my palate is tainted by the 51st Ward The Krispy Karl I just sampled. This is very hoppy, but the malt character just isnt there. Not well balanced at all. Take my review with a grain of salt, since my experience is atypical it seems.
Pours with a thick head due to the bottle conditioning. Nice malt build with a very balanced body. Carmel and a bit of sweetness are whet I get from this.

Bouteille 12-01-2015. Superbe bière ambrée avec une mousse intense. Superbe nez de fruits confits, de houblons, dagrumes. Une bouche savoureuse, mordante, intense sans être désagréable. Finale amère déconcertante, cest ce quon recherche chez une amber ale; un équilibre entre les malts et les houblons.

Bottle - This one was a little too bitter for my taste. I like an amber ale that has character, but not too much bitterness. It does have a nice creamy mouthfeel, that I like, with some raisin and dark fruit notes hidden under the bitterness. Overall, solid, but too bitter for me.

Bottle from Maine Tap Room. Pours Amber with a white head. Lots of citrus hop notes on the nose. Big hop flavor on the tongue. I'm not sure how much malt is there but it's pretty flavorful with a nice amount of bitterness on the finish. Interesting take on an often dull style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle, from Old Line Fine Wine, Spirits & Bistro. Appearance is a light reddish brown color with a half inch light tan head. Aroma is grassy, earthy hop aroma with a heavy malt presence. Taste is bitterness to start things out, and then toasty, and slightly sweet malt comes in. Palate is a hop bite with medium carbonation. Overall, nicely balanced and very good representation from Maine.

Pours a dark ruby red/chestnut brown color with copper colored edges and a frothy, two finger yellowish-beige head that very slowly settles into a thick, lasting cap. Good retention, possibly too much so, with signs of over carbonation. The pillowy foam head takes forever to settle and coated the glass with soapy lacing on the way down. 

Dank, floral aroma with a prominent earthy hop presence thats countered by a sweet malt backbone. Earthy and spicy with resinous oils, grassy pine, spruce tip and fresh buds followed by subtle tropical fruit and malt sweetness. Theres a touch of grapefruit and citrus zest along with caramel malt, toffee, biscuit and vinous fruit. Theres a stronger malt presence than I usually prefer in hoppy beers but it works really well in the nose of this beer. 

Full bodied with a blast of dry, earthy hop bitterness that lingers over the sweet malt backbone into a bone dry finish. Sticky with resinous hop oils, subtle spiciness, grassy pine and earthy, soil-like flavor. Good hop flavor but not as complex as the nose suggests. A bit one dimensional and lacking the citrus/tropical fruit sweetness found in the aroma. Fortunately, there is plenty of flavorful malt sweetness filling this need and balancing things out nicely. Strong caramel malt presence with hints of toffee, biscuit, toast and subtle dark fruit sweetness. Really well balanced and easy to drink with no heat whatsoever. The malt backbone perfectly counters the dry bitterness of the earthy, floral hops. Similar to Zoe but more flavorful and better balanced in my opinion. I could drink several of these in one sitting.

Clear red brown colour, off-white head. Hoppy aroma, pine, fruity hops, toast, bread. Bitter flavour, sweet malts, light red fruits. Bitter finish, bread, caramel. (from 66cL can @ Milos place. Thanks for sharing!)
Nice rich amber color with a rocky beige head. Aroma of hops, citrus juice, sweet caramel malt. Red ales really arent my favorite but this one is pretty good.
500ml bottle shared by Bvery...thanks! Cloudy amber pour with minimal head. Minimal hop and malt aroma. Taste is in your face hops but finishes really nice. Good stuff.
Bottle. Murky amber pour with a soapy rocky head. Hop forward - earthy, some pine. A bit dank. Amazing amber.

On the side of the bottle reads "042815."
This was poured into a nonic pint glass.
The appearance was a two finger white foamy rocky head that dissipated in about a minute and a half. Light stringy lacing sticks in a semi-thick sort of fashion.
The smell starts off with a citrus zest with the citrus rind running over top of a light caramel presence. Its there for the style but doesnt show a whole lot of depth.
The taste is mainly bitter through the citrus zest and rind. Sweet is only there to balance in the caramel, but even that isnt exactly balanced once again. Bitter citrus aftertaste that leads into a sliding bitter citrus finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability about it. Carbonation packs enough sharpness but still allows the bitterness to display most of the sharpness.
Overall, for an American Red/Amber ale, this one is a bit more hoppier than others. Might not necessarily be a session beer, but more likely one just to enjoy as is.

bottle provided by French Frey .. . pours a dark amber .. medium head, strong lacing .. . whats italy? .. . red malt, borgoune, and reduced pancake syrup .. . mouth is fine, as is the finish .. a decent amber .. . . paul oakenfold, exclusively on radio one.

Bomber fun whole foods. Really nice looking amber red with very little carbonation but a gigantic head. Smell is hop forward, a bit different than you?d expect considering the look. It takes minutes for the head to dissipate. Aroma is pineapple and citrus. Mouthfeel is a bit off for me. It?s a bit thick. Not enough carbonation for me. The taste is ok. Some caramel at the end. I don?t love this one, but it gets the benefit of the doubt because of the brewery.
Solid red ale, has a nice malt structure and when you can get it fresh, the hops come through nicely.
bottle. amber red with one finger head. malty caramel base, lightly sweet with a fruity nature. medium hops with mild bitterness. excellent.
Im not a big fan of reds. This one is fairly hoppy. Moderate malt. Great color.

A very tasty red with great hop notes. Slightly bitter but good palate of honey and butterscotch. Pours a deep reddish brown. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at Meadhall, 4/9/15Clear auburn-magenta colored body looks very appealing, topped by a beige head that is well-retained.Pine, iced tea, candied oranges, white grapefruit and wintergreen in the nose all speak to the specialty malts (must be crystal...and yes, I see that is the case looking at the commercial description) mixing with the aggressive citrus and pine of the columbus hops. A bit of odd buttercream-like note with warming, which I dont think is diacetyl but rather some odd aromatic from one of the malts. No alcohol in the nose.Bitter up front; very much so. Resin and dry grapefruit/orange rind immediately assert themselves while the classic this-is-why-you-shouldnt-put-crystal-malts-in-an-I Pale ale effect is immediately felt; that being an iced tea-like flavor with a very hard, (think hard candy texture, like a jolly rancher) texture to the beer and some toasted malt dryness with a complete lack of balancing sweetness. Ive been pretty outspoken on not putting crystal malts in an ipa and for that matter, may as well leave out most of the other specialty malts too. Throw in a bit of debittered black malt if you want the color and maybe just a touch of special B if you really want your hop-focused beer to have some weird malt notes that dont work with the hop flavors....Anyways, back to the beer. Its massively bitter with no balancing malt sweetness or even a soft texture for the hops to sink in to. As is, it just assaults the palate and the acidity builds up on the finish. Furthermore, despite having amarillo in the hop bill, there seems to be only a passing fruitiness from it that is easily outclassed by the bully that is columbus. While falconers flight has a lot of enjoyable hops in it (simcoe and sorachi ace are awesome), its still very high in alpha acids and seems to be abused here, leading to more detrimental acidity and unbalance. In summary, I did not like this beer.
Nice stuff. Full of flavor, with snappy lemon hops. Pours amber red with good head and lacing. Fits in as the light cousin of all their bigger hoppier beers. Tap at Churchkey.

8 oz. draft at Tørst in Brooklyn, New York. The pour is a slight haze orange ruby with a bigger off white head. Great lace left on the glass. The aroma is big and chewy citrus fruit, toast malt and dank. The taste is a clean blend of caramel malt and the juicy big fresh hops. Really delicious. The palate is medium bodied, active carbonation and a clean dry finish. Very impressed with every Maine Beer I have had so far.

Arômes de caramel salé, muscade, orange et poivre. En bouche, goût de caramel, pamplemousse, orange et poivre. La finale est amère, poivrée et courte. On sent des effluves de sucre candi. La texture est liquoreuse et une belle mousse épaisse couronne le liquide.

4 oz taster at Churchkey. Pours a clear dark golden/amber color with a medium plus sized creamy off white head. The aroma and flavor have nice juicy, citrus, grapefruit, toasted malts, grass, decent bitterness and flavor. Soft finish.
Deep ruddy pour, off-white head. Great aroma of earthy malt, mango, guava, grapefruit, herbs and pot. Flavor is grapefruit, dank earth, spice, and pine.
Bottle from Capones. Pours turbid ruby with 2-finger, frothy khaki head. Nose is heavy resiny hops, caramel malt, vinous fruit. Tastes hoppy, malty, fruity, well balanced, and delicious.

1100th review!!!. Pours murkey copper-amber with a two finger off white head with excellent lacing. Aroma is of citrus, pine, tropical fruits, toasted bready malts, rains, figs, light dankness, and some light caramel sweet malts. Taste is of fresh citrus, pine, rains, figs, tropical fruits, toasted bread, sweet malts, caramel, herbal hops,and some light toffee. Has a medium body with a pretty creamy mouthfeel and a moderately bitter, semi dry, pretty long finish. Overall, a excellent red IPA that is pretty hoppy, but still has some nice malts in the background.
UPDATED: APR 5, 2015 When you read the description they state it was not just a standard red. It?s more a red ipa. Very good aroma. Nice coloring. Deep hops. Bottle
Pours a dark somewhat cloudy orange. Nice hoppy aroma. Good balance between hop flavor and malt flavor. Very tasty brew!

Not too many breweries make a truly red ale. They tend to be classified as an amber ales or Red IPA or American Strong Ale. But with Red Wheelbarrow, Maine Beer Company has succeeded in making a beer thats neither of those styles and is more of its own thing. Plenty hoppy to be sure, but not extremely so. The palette is pretty well balanced for the most part and its drinker-friendly. If only it werent so expensive.

I poured a 500ml bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 11/25/14 and cost $7.99 ($0.47 per ounce).

Appearance: Deep shade of burgundy/blood red. Very cloudy body. Pours to a large, tan, foamy head that laces and retains extremely well.

Smell: Fruity scent of berries and citrus; some flowers.

Taste: Berry isnt a flavor you tend to get in beers that arent made with some kind of fruit extract or puree. I do detect a slight strawberry or raspberry quality to this beer, though. Ill chalk that up to the fairly odd combination of Columbus, Amarillo, and Falconers Flight hops. Orange seems to be quite prominent as well. Theres a fairly strong malty presence here; creating for distinct sweetness and minor bready flavor (maybe even some fruitcake). It finishes with an overtly bitter sensation, its dry but washes away clean. Its more than just a solid brew, but not quite to the point of being amazing. Definitely one of the best red ales I can recall having, though.

Drinkability: At 7% ABV, Red Wheelbarrow is a strong beer in the classic sense, but surprisingly light in delivery. The mouthfeel is full, soft, well-carbonated and comfortable. Not refreshing, but in no way a challenge to get down. The alcohol is barely noticeable, though I appreciate the robustness of the palette. Versatile enough to stand up to a meal, but tasty enough to enjoy a single bottle by itself.
Bottle from Philly Craft. Nice notes of caramel, pine and Earth. Mild citrus finish. Color was amber / copper. Medium body. Well done.
Definitely raisin and fig aroma. Medium body with roasted malty backbone. Pale dry finish. Decent take for a red ale and worth a shot.

Fresh 500 ml bottle. Slightly hazy Amber color with lasting retention. Aroma is fruity and a solid amount of resin. Body has a big bread and caramel to balance the hop profile. Citrus that transitions into pine that end very clean. I dont drink many Amber ales because they are normally very boring. This is one of the best in style I have ever sampled, great update of the style. Nicely crafted.
Amber pour with thin white head. Aroma is grapefruit and pine. Taste follows nose with noticeable pineapple. Enjoyable.

clear reddish Amber pour with a soft beige head and sticky lacing .... Aroma of roasted malts, chewy caramel malts, citrusy grapefruity hops and some piney hops with toffee and dark fruits .... Taste is of roasted malts, bitter rindy grapefruity hops, some piney hops and a rich caramel malt ... Touch of toffee and dark fruits to it as well .... Has some oily slickness in the mouthfeel ... Finish is bitter .... Nice red ale
A good drinking and well hopped amber, though this beer is taste-wise a step below their regular series. Great hop aroma.
Bottle. Cloudy copper red with large spongy beige head, floral hops aroma, medium carbonation, hoppy taste, long finish. A very hoppy beer.

500ml bottle courtesy of mikeq215. Thanks. POurs a hazy amber color with a big clumpy off0white head that has fantastic retention and oodles of crazy lazing. The aroma is big and bold with pine, citrus and roasted barley. The taste favors pine with toffee malts somewhere in the background. The palate is medium in viscosity and the carbonation is soft. Finishes long, dry and bitter. Overall: Fine Amber.

Got in a BIF from ZebraCakez. 500 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 11/4/2014. Pours hazy deep ruby red color with a 2 finger dense and fluffy light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, caramel, toast, brown sugar, light toffee, and floral/grassy earthiness. Very nice aromas with good complexity and balance of big citrus/tropical hops and moderate dark/bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, pineapple, pine, caramel, toast, brown sugar, light toffee, and floral/toasted earthiness. Fair amount of pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon/orange zest, pine, caramel, toast, brown sugar, light toffee, and floral/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity and robustness of citrus/tropical hops and dark/bready malt flavors; with a good malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, fairly creamy, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very nice red ale. All around good complexity, balance, and robustness of bright citrus/tropical hops and moderate dark/bready malt sweetness; and very smooth to drink for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

A crack of the cap and a hop-fruity aroma wafts towards me, the ruby-brown fluid fills my glass to about halfway and then up comes the head, thick, wet and gleaming, easily taking over half the glass. The scent is heady, making me think of dark fruits for decadent pie fillings. The foam recedes, and I finish pouring the glass, take the picture and bring the glass to my lips for a first taste. Hops are very apparent in the flavor, but the malty fruit accents are predominant and seem to lean towards a roasted nutty taste as it warms. As tasty a beer as I have in a while, this has excellent flavors, and a gloriously balanced bitterness is keeping me interested in every sip. Boredom comes easy if a beer isnt welcoming me with all its qualities, but this one has my attention! I taste the bitterness in the back of my throat, thick and rich...very exciting.
The medium body is sticky and a little thick, the carbonation is perfect for carrying over the flavors and texture of this brew. The finish is nice; it stays a little, and then says goodbye with a smile and a nod and although it is big while its here, its finish is short and sweet and the physical experience is gone in minutes. The memory is lasting...

500 ml bottle to snifter (bottled 11/25/14; shared with the Mrs.). Looks good; a hazy fuller amber with foamy off-white head. Smells bitterly hoppy and malty with a bittersweet backbone alongside notes of caramel and a bit of toastiness. Tastes like it smells with a medium to medium full-bodied mouthfeel. A bit of fig as well. Could be lighter and dryer, but enjoyable nonetheless.

Bottle. The pour is a vibrant red and orange with a nice think head. The aroma is mostly hops, not as strong as an ipa with hop aroma, but not far off either. The taste is a mix of the best parts of a red ale and the smooth hops of an ipa. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an opaque reddish amber with a huge off white head...great lacing and retention. Aroma is very hoppy and resinous...earthy with some caramely malts. Flavor follows suit...a bit too much roasty/bready malts for my taste but earthy/piney hops save the day...fresh and floral. Mouthfeel is medium and lively with a dry earthy/bready/piney finish.

B.500 ml 
Aroma: bottom of amber malts with nice rounded feel, top hop forward set up. Straight up, but works well. 
Look: poured as clear dark amber with large foamy lasting cap. Thick lace covering on glass. 3+
Body/Taste/Palate: full bodied with soft textures. Milder carbonation. Nice, refined skill shown on rather simple formula. Good sugar/malt play with hoop plus body and water. It is what you would expect from MBC brand.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2015 Pours a bubbly off white head with a brownish red body from bottle into a wine glass. Aroma is fairly hoppy in a slightly citrusy way. Taste is hop forward with a tiny bit of sweetness. Not overly bitter, but tastes of fresh mildly citrus hops. Moderate crisp carbonation and a body that?s a littler thinner than medium. Feels a little rye and its very dry and crisp

Bottle for xmas, thanks Nancy! Pours a deep reddish Amber, beige head. Aroma is toffee, citrus, grapefruit, bready malt, caramel, pine, grass. Flavor is complex caramely malt backbone with massive fresh burst of piney and fruity hops, Dankness. This is a really lovely red ale, when it's super fresh.

Consumed (unfortunately) 2.5 months after the date on the bottle.Cloudy light-brown to deep, muddy-yellowish-garnet with a cm of pancake batter head caked on top. Aroma is an assertive caramel with pine, sap, and grapefruit to match. Body is surprisingly (given the caramel and color) very light, watery-oily, with a creamy/fine carbonation and light burn. Flavor is strongly balanced towards floral grapefruit, some lemon, earth, and sap, and a very dark caramel note. The caramel is much more restrained, less chewy, slightly darker, and maybe even slightly burnt compared with the aroma. More of it comes through here as it warms though. A very nice amber, amazing body, nice use of malt/hop balance in flavor. The aroma doesnt hit you from a foot away like it does for their beers < 1 month old.

Malt driven nose with some stuff I could not put my finger on, but I dont think it was raisin or fig. Interesting, yes a bit of toffee/caramel too. The color is fabulous, Dark glowing orange, murky, lots of small carbonation visible, thick robust head, leaves rings of lacing. Taste has plenty of hoppiness, and dryness, tempered with a bit of toffee. Liked it. Well made.
Ruddy brown with an above average head. Hreat lattice. Florallly hop nose. Another solidly balanced beer from this brewery. Enjoyable.

500ml bottle from Beer Culture, New York

Pours dark reddish with a thick white head. Aroma of caramely malts, herbal hops, grassy notes, grass and toffee. Taste is crisp, malty and hoppy with some caramel, toffee and bitterness. Finish is smooth, sweetish and crisp malty with some caramel, toffee and grassy hoppiness. Quite tasty malty and hoppy amber ale.

Bottle at home, courtesy of Lukaduke. Thanks again man!! Pour is deep roasted amber-brown with pillowy cream-colored head and great lacing. Big grapefruit, caramelly, resinous, somewhat roasty, sweet brown sugar, grassy and floral aroma. Taste is big grapefruit, orange marmalade, light resin, sweet malty, some toasted sugars, bready, and prunes with a medium bitter finish. Full body with high carbonation. Really nice full bodied, hoppy Amber. Tasty stuff.
500ml bottle pours a red amber color with a lot of frothy head. Rich malt flavor and medium hoppiness that balances nicely. Full hop flavor that lingers.

Bottle from shelf. Gusher. Pours a murky light brown with a light tan head. Aromas of floral and citrus hops. Taste is semi dry and bitter. Flavors of fresh cut grass, flower petals. Some juicy tropical hop expression. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Finishes juicy and bitter. Pretty nice.
Bottle from Julios, nice dark reddish amber beer with good amounts of body and just too much malt for me, perhaps faded hops after 2 months in a bottle but likely just meant to be hearty though.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, hazy reddish pour with white head, aroma brought red fruits, caramel, toffee, biscuit, pine, grass, some spice notes with a hint of raisin. Taste had a mix of grass, bread, toast, some caramel, nice hints of orange and red fruits with raisin as well, finishing bitter, slightly sweet.

large head on pour...citrus hops smell, taste is almost all hops...too much/too bitter for me...hint of maltyness that is of english ale sort...slightly fruity taste that comes out between the hops bitternessas it ages on you...

Pours a very brownish red with a mountain of frothy off-white head that stays forever. Wild and crazy lacing. Nose is first citrusy hops and underneath dried fruits. The fruitiness explodes on the palate with a very well-balanced blend of hoppy bitterness and malty sweetness. Medium body; vigorous carbonation. Very nice brew!

Ive gotta hand it to MBC; while everyone else is making bourbon barrel-aged stouts and exotic sour ales, they can brew up an amber ale that is every bit as good, almost single-handedly dragging the style up to respectability.

Anyway, this one is strong and hoppy for the style. Spruce and resin hops, tangerine, and caramel malt. Not very sweet, a little too bitter but still very good.

Serving: Bottle Fire Works Leesburg. It pours a ruddy amber color with a dense head. The nose is a mix of dried fruit, earthy hops, a little citrus, and a touch of caramel. Nice balance up front on the tongue with the hops winning out eventually. Medium bodied with lower carbonation and a lingering finish. A very nice example of an American take on the style.

500ml bottle from Bottles and Cans. Pours reddish amber with a bit of a foamy head. Lacing died quickly after the head, to almost nothing. Aroma has sweet dark fruits and some malt. Quite American Strong-ish. Taste is of sweet fruits, some dark stone fruits, some malt. Medium bodied and sweetly stickly. Finishes mostly sweet, but not to a cloying point. Solid red with a lot of flavor. 14.2

Bottle. Amber pour with small lacy head. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, light hop. Taste is lightly sweet, malty, light toffee notes. Palate is well attenuated, rather dry, smooth carbonation. Very clean, very well done and probably an excellent Amber ale according to the style but I cant shake the question Why brew this?

Got a bottle while in Chicago. Pours a dark thick red. A thick coating sticky white head. A fresh fruity aroma that is very interesting and original. Almost fruity pebble like. Very nice. A very fruity flavor. Very nice feel and clean taste as always from this brewery. Fruit flavors all over this thing. A slight caramel taste mixed in. It has a little sharper and more full flavor. Still drinkable. Definitely one of the best ambers Ive had. Good stuff.

On tap at brewery. Pours cloudy dark amber/brown with off white head. Citrus aroma with malt dried fruit and pine. Flavor starts off sweet caramel malt and golden raisins followed by citrus and tropical fruit. Finishing with grapefruit. Excellent brew!

9/27/2014. 22 oz. bottle. Red-brown with a tan head. Floral, hoppy aromas, so fresh and fruity. Dried fruit, malt, caramel and loads of hops. Everything goes together in perfect harmony. One of the best amber ales out there.

Grabbed this while in Charleston. Pours copper with thick off white head. Scent is a touch of citrus and grain. A little hop forward for my liking. Would like a bit more balance. Bottle - Bottles - Charleston, SC

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2014 Bottle thanks to trade with jdb288! Pours a slightly hazy copper with big fluffy tan head that leaves good lace. Aroma of big caramel masks and a touch of pine hops. Taste is like a nice malt forward IPA, bitterness is present, earthy pine hops, yet still nice malt sweetness. Good stuff.

Bottle from Lukaduke. Poured gently and still have me a massive eggshell head, rising above an oversized pint glass. Some typical "red malt" aromas backed with heavy American hops. Caramel, raisin, pine, citrus all show up on taste. Balanced and well made but just a style I dont get too excited about.

Grapefruit and tangerine nose, caramel accents. Cloudy auburn, thick yellow head. Whole orange, cherry and dried leaves, chewy caramel. Medium body, smooth, very light carbonation. Cask-like smoothness and nuances. Amber ales are among my least favorite styles because they are usually so meh, but I would enjoy drinking this all day, everyday. Fantastic and the model for this style.

Bottle at WF Columbus Circle. Deep reddish-brown, cloudy, high foamy head. Great nose, caramel, pine, earth, cinnamon, orange. Very hoppy falvor, great citrus, pine caramel. Perfect balance. Prickly, small carbonation. Peppery, spicy finish. Great as usual from Maine.

Bottle from DeBucas. Pours out a light-to-medium amber-copper color with a frothy light tan head that stays around a long time. Flowery-malt aromas. Body is on the medium-light side. Roasty notes with layers of perfume and spice. Sorta muddled overall.

Bottle. Amber, big light tan head. Aroma is pine, dark fruit, and toast. The taste adds raisin at first, some caramel and citrus, and big hoppy bitterness on the finish. Low carb and light mouthfeel at first with a very rich, bitter coating on the finish. Ive had this one in the past - I like it more each time I try it. Another very unique MBC beer in its own category. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Amber-reddish color, Clear and dark red. Aroma of hops, wheat, flowers, grass, caramel and yeast. Taste is strong red hops, little bit of citrus, malt, raisins and alcohol. Tons of foam on this baby. Solid amber offering.

Moi qui ne voulait plus boire de amber ale. Mais quand cest Maine qui brasse, disons que cest autre chose. Beau corps rouge qui garde sa mousse précieusement. Le nez tricote des arômes de malts terreux et épicés avec des parfums de conifères et dagrumes de toute sorte. Le goût mise à la fois sur des houblons américains et sur des céréales qui donnent une impression de seigle et de fruits. En bouche, le liquide a une belle densité avec un bon apport de bulles et une texture crémeuse. La finale est florale et forestière, épicée et caramélisée. Bien content de ce choix.

Bottled August 12, 2014.
Glass: Duvel tulip.
Appearance: Murky amber/red with way too much head, tall and foamy.
Aroma: The aroma is malty and piney with a dash of citrus. I sort of like it, there are hints of caramel nicely strung throughout.
Taste: Malty with a bready, toasty and caramel backing along with a big pine and citrus presence. Not bad, easy to drink, I sort of love it, but am sort of bored of it.
Palate: Full-bodied, moderately carbonated. Coats the mouth.
Overall: I like this a lot to just drink, but thinking about it its not a great beer. I dunno. The price value isnt there though.

Bottle. Pours a ruby/caramel with a three finger, cream coloured head that sticks. Aroma has great notes of citrus, pine, caramel, a bit of bread. Really nice. Taste is balanced with notes of resin, pine, caramel, and a short finish. Medium body and carbonation. Clean in the mouth with a lively carbonation and a bone dry finish. Overall an awesome beer. Balanced caramel/piney flavours with a great mouth feel.
Pours a soft red-orange with a tawny head. Nose is malty and kind of chalky, piney notes. Definitely vitaminy and chalky, pine notes.
Nice amber color floral piney aroma smooth drinking with a nice hop flavors not overpowering.

Pours a red color and mildly hazy with a tan head. Aroma of grapefruit, caramel, biscuits. Taste was mostly what the nose brought. I got some pine, or maybe a bit of spruce as well. It was sweet, but not overly sweet. Body was medium, carb was perfect, and this was a decent brew. Not my favorite from Maine, but I have yet to have one that I dislike.

I would call this a red ale, not an amber, which I perceive as being a different style. I havent looked at the malt bill on this one, but Im getting strong rye notes. Theres a hint of spiciness, and a good dollop of hoppiness. Good.

A reddish amber body with a thick beige head that faded to a minor coating, good lacing. Aroma had a nice kick of grapefruit hops initially, a good balance of bread and caramel malts, and a bit of pine hops. Flavor had a nice sweetness through out. Hops were surprisingly well balanced. Grapefruit hops were certainly robust and the pine hops were assertive. I also had notes of mild dark fruits and bread. Finish was nice and dry. A full bodied beer.
Dark brown. Murky nice head fades fast. Nose is bitter with lemon and cloves. Taste is a minor sweetness. Lots of tangerine with cinnamon and apples. Peppery finish.

Thanks, jlindros.  Pours a nice bright, reddish, copper-ish amber color. It seems to be fairly hazy, though it is a bit hard to tell. The head is cream colored and puffs up quite nicely. Easy to swirl back up, as well. Lots of little bubbles. Good lacing and retention. Lots of hops in the aroma. Im getting earthy and fruity flavors: berries, citrus, grass, pine, spice. The hops dominate, but theres a solid malt character underneath. Toasty caramel and brown sugar. Mild bready sweetness. Good dose of nutty flavor. Mild vanilla. The taste is dry, particularly for the style, and medium bitter. Dried out crystal malt caramel backbone with that spicy, earthy, fruity hoppiness on top. Starts off with honey and caramel before the grapefruit rind and pine resin bitterness takes over, bringing with it all of the more delicate hop notes, as well. Lots of hop flavor in finish, which hits with a nice shot of bitterness and lingering fruit. Prickly carbonation. Seems a touch higher than most Ambers. Light feel for a 7% abv beer, not really surprising since its rather dry. I dont love the style, but this is an excellent example and a very well made beer. Its dry and bitter with good flavor. Easy to drink. Seems like it would go great with pizza.

Aroma: Bready Malts, Floral, Mild Citrus

Appearance: Amber Hue, Passes Mild Light, White Head, Great Lacing

Taste: Bready Malts, Piney, Mildly Floral, Mildly Bittering Hops

Mouthfeel: Great Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Bitter

All of the beers from these guys are so good. Ruby Amber pour, super head and good lacing. Pungent alcohol and caramel aroma. Caramel malts, floral hops with light citrus notes. Nice burn. This thing is perfectly balanced. If I didnt have to sell my children for medical experimentation, I would drink these fellas beer all the time.

Amber pour. Eggshell colored very thick head. Danky hop aroma and caramel sweetness. Flavor is also dank and sweet. A little vegetal. Crisp medium sweet finish. 

---Rated via iPhone
Sweet malt aroma with a light amount of hops. Clear red color with a large tan head. Light sweet beginning with a mild bitter finish. Moderately creamy palete.

16.9 oz. bottle. Poured deep hazy ruby with fluffy light khaki head. Remarkable lacing. Flavor is some roasted malt with raisin and figs. Also some grapefruit present. Lively carbonation, slightly silky mouthfeel. Dry finish. The overall quality of these Maine beers just oozes from every bottle.

Bottle from Norms in Vienna, VA. Pours a murky orange/red with an off white head. Citrus hop nose. Med body with layers of biscuit and citrus hop flavors. Light fruits linger. Strong bitter finish with lingering citrus.

New Beer Distributors, NYC 50cl ($8): Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma is mostly hoppy (somewhat herbal, fruity, citrus), a hint of booze, and plenty of malts. Taste is mellow at the front then gets progressively more bitter into the finish and comes off with a nice lingering hoppy aftertaste. The sugary malt backbone provides a nice undertone throughout. Unsurprisingly, everything is excellently balanced. Once again, no complaints.

Aroma is malty and earthy. Almost like a rye beer though there doesn't appear to be any rye in it. Not much hops in the nose but a hint of flowery hops behind the malt. Hazy copper/red color with a wonderful fluffy cream colored head. A well balanced beer with earthy and slight citrus notes. Must admit my palate might be a bit wonky from the cigar I had just before but it works well with the stogie. Very nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the 650 ml. bottle stamped 042214. It pours a medium amber with reddish hues, a tremendous cream colored foamy head, and good clarity. The first thing I pick up in the aroma is floral and pine hops with a good malt backbone kind of bringing up the rear. The body is medium and smooth. The taste has a durable roasted barley malt quality with a strong bitterness due to all the hops. Got some zing this does.

Pours a darker amber with a full, smooth, lingering, off white head. The aroma is fruity, with grapefruit, pineapple, peach, some floral hops, a bit of lemon, and light caramel. The taste is more dry with some bitterness to it. Here I find a healthy amount of pine and grapefruit up front, which than extends into softer fruity notes. These include peach, lemon, and hints of pineapple. Aftertaste is shorter and is grapefruit and pineapple. Medium bodied, slick textured, with above average carbonation. This is another solid offering from the Maine Beer Company.

Hazy red and brown tainted orange hue topped by a creamy off-white head that slowly fades. Fruity, sappy, coniferous hop-focused nose. Strong red fruits, both from esters and hops I believe and amplified by the very toasty, caramelized malts giving a jammy, fruit rich and almost juicy presence, but to me, kinda clashing with the caramel flavours to form a candy-like fruit bar, that could always work on its own, but in the second half and finish in mouth, gets completely demolished by the agressive bitter wave, laden with citric acid. Those hops are pitiless, more intense on the bitter than aromatic end. Meanwhile, the carbonation is pristine, well tuned as is always the case with Maine Beer Co, and this certainly helps, but the candy feel detracts from the mouthfeel enjoyment. I could not get into that one, no fatal flaws per se, but the balance just did not tune at all with my palate. And it ended up not being enjoyable and tough to finish.

(Bottled on March 25th 2014) Pours a hazy amber with medium, thick tan head. Good retention and beautiful lace. Aroma is hop-forward with notes of tropical fruit, grapefruit and spruce. Oily texture, medium carbonation, medium body and a very balanced finish that is neither too bitter nor too sweet. Very easy to drink and nicely complex aromatics.

Pint bottle, which I got from Perfect Pour. Shared with caterwaul and Andrew K. Bottled 4/22/14. Totally hazy dark red color. Good thin khaki head. Leaves good thicker lace. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of crisp, lightly soft lighter carbonation. Lightly dry finish. A little prickly. Some tropical fruity hop notes. Spicy, light peppery notes. Interesting clean malt bill. Seeing some of the raisin. Some grapefruit citrus. Moderate bitter taste, light to moderate sweet. Kind of spicy. 7% alcohol is noticeable but not bothersome. Solid, interesting beer overall. Kind of spicy, not as smooth and velvety as other Maine beers Ive tried, though. I prefer the others from this brewery. Andrew K. says it tastes stronger than it is.
Bottled of course, red brown pour, lots of off white/beige head. Malts, some hop character and a bit of fruits - sort of the like the Ommegang Fire &Blood red ale thats out currently.

A refreshing and drinkable brew, pours a pleasant clear amber with lots of natural foam and lacing. Has an appetizing caramel malt aroma. Taste is malty and finishes with a mildly-earthy bitterness. Strikes me as very "fresh" tasting. Solid bitterness but not really hoppiness
picked up from my last trip east. deep red, billowing cream hued head. lots of citrus, pineapple, moderate bitterness. some malt. medium to full body.

Bottle into tulip. Reddish-brown color, lingering dirty white head. Carmel malt and resinous hops in the nose. In the mouth the malt is more restrained than I expected for a red, and the hops in the back too assertive. A blend of a red and IPA -- interesting if I was in the mood for an IPA, but as I was expecting more of malt-prominent red Im turned off by the excessive hops.

Bottled 05-20-14 so about two weeks old. Pour has a red amber color with a two finger tan head that retained very well. Aroma has punchy hops, citrus, resins, pine, and plenty of supporting malt. Mouth feel is medium and there is plenty of carbonation. Flavor again is loaded with hops, citrus, resins, and pine, but has a chewy well malted side as well.

From a bottle. Pours hazy copper red with a bubbly off white head. Tastes like bitter grains, astringent grapefruit, malt, and herbs. Light body and low carbonation. Smells malty and like dry grapefruit and sweet nutty citrus.

Bottle. Pours bright red with creamy beige head. Aroma is bready and toasted malts, light caramel, spicy and floral hops, raisins, and faint dates. Flavor is strong hop presence with some toasted malts, some dark fruit esters, and faint grassiness; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Bottle from Perfect Pour shared by sonnycheeba. Pours a reddish amber with a layer of off white head. Aroma of hops and grasses. Taste is crisp, with grasses again and some citrus/lemon.

Pours a hazy honey brown with a bit of something ruby in it. A fat tan head of persistent foam that left lace and dwindled slowly to a layer on top. Nose is toasty bread, crusty, grainy and earthy with a touch of grass. Some citrus peel in the nose and a light caramel. Taste is a bit hoppier than I would like for an amber. It has plenty of toasty bread and sweet caramel that are out shined on the palate by hop forward flavors like grapefruit. It has the earthy pith and the peel of the grapefruit, and a bit of hop bitter too. It lost some of the caramel and bread to the hops in the dry finish. medium body with plenty of carbonation.

I liked it well enough but I think its a touch too hoppy to be an amber.

Bottle. Pours a opaque amber with thick head. Aroma of grapefruits, earth, roated malts, vegetables and caramel. Taste is bitter citrusy hops with some biscuity malts malts. Mediu mouthfeel with lively carbonation. Decent amber but far from my favourite from these guys.

Bottle. Pours hazy amber with a medium sized off white head that stays awhile. The aroma has a huge hop presence with a bit of citrus and Caramel. The taste has a big hop punch and is well balanced. Plenty of bitterness and reminds me of a better version of hop back.

50cl bottle. Large beige head atop lightly hazed dark amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, orange, some grapefruit, caramel. Taste is moderately sweet, orange, some caramel, light strawberry, grapefruit. Light-medium body, light stickiness.

Refrigerated 0.5 L brown bottle, April 22, 2014 bottled on date.  Pours clear amber with big off-white head. Aroma is piney hops, light body, and thick bubble lacing. Taste is piney hops, herbal hops, and bitter finish.

(500ml bottle) cloudy orange, soapy tan/creamy bubbles. Nose of brown sugar, candied citrus, cream, pine. Taste of bitter pine, sell matched sweetness, bready, biscuit, cream. Citrus zest, creamy body but bitter finish.

I must have gotten a bad bottle or something. Really liked all the other beers Ive tried from these guys. Clear red pour with a slight tan head. Odd nose to this one. Weird. Smells like a solvent. Drain pour.
This was a huge beer with a great head. There was lots of fruit and hops. I thought this more of an IPA than anything else.
Excellent American ale. Mud drink fresh, and when you do you will not be disappointed.

Poured from 500ml bottle into a tulip: Pours dark red with a fluffy tan head with decent lacing. Aroma of caramel, resin, dark fruit, and malt. Taste is caramel, raisins, currants, nuts, pine hop flavor, and a bit of citrus. Its a little sweet up front but is well balanced with the hops..Definitely more of an IPA than an amber... this is classified incorrectly. Medium body slightly sticky mouthfeel, perfect carbonation. This is a really nice beer.

Bottle at home. Pours clear dark amber with a large, foamy beige head, long retention with good lacing. Aroma is caramel and cookie malt, light toast and nutty notes with apple and pear esters, citrus, floral and earthy hops. Flavor is sweet malt, candied fruits, medium hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Hoppy, IPA-like aroma with pine, citrus, dark fruit, and caramel malt. Malty, bittersweet flavor with nuts, bread and citrus. Pine citrus bitterness in the finish. Not a typical red by any means (more of an IPA), but really good nonetheless.
Bottle. Pours orange/amber with an off white head. Aroma of pine, caramel, malt. Taste is citrus fruits, hops, caramel, lots of malt. Medium body with a bitter finish.

Bottle pour at BGH. Pours a opaque orange amber. Some hops on the nose. Nice, full body, subtle hoppy flavor. Nice

This one poured a nice mahogany color with a white head. Aroma was of caramel and toasted malt, and citrusy and floral hops. Flavor was similar, a really fresh crisp hoppy amber alle, like a better hopback.
Cooper red firing up the kiln producing clouds of tan head. Sweet aroma malt flavor with tart hop finish. Interesting and different.

Poured from 500 ml bottle. 

Lightly hazy, dark copper orange with a huge khaki head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of pine, caramel, bread and citrus. Despite the "hop forward" description this beer has plenty of malt. 

Taste of grapefruit, pine, caramel and orange. The flavor is hoppier than the aroma. 

Medium body and medium carbonation.

Bottle. This poured with a giant head over the top of a rusty brew. It delivers a big, crispy aroma. Sweet and candied with a slippery tongue. The finish is like a crisp green apple. Fun. (#5492, 4/20/2014)

One of the better reds Ive had in a while. This pours a deep red, and on the nose there is a lot of pine and caramel. On the palate, pine, citrus, grass, and a lemon zest come through. Caramel and bread on the finish. This really drinks more like an IPA than an amber, but it is good.
Pour is ruby/orange with a large off-white head. Aroma and flavor of citrus, light caramel, grapefruit, and mineral water (?). Finish is sweet and hoppy.

500ml bottle. Amber/red pour, big fluffy head. Smell is citrus, slight dank, and lots of malt. Flavor is nice, zesty citrus, bit dry but plenty of malt flavor. Nice brew. Overpriced as fuck though, glad i didnt buy it.

Bottle. Strawberry, pine, and citrus hops in the nose. Fresh. Some nice caramel aroma as well. Hazy ruddy bronze under a rocky, tawny beige foam. Sweet caramel and toffee holding up a huge, somewhat grassy, citrus and cat pee hops. Assertive bitterness that just barely tips the balance towards bitter. Medium body, high carbonation, crisp with a lingering bitter finish.

Is there a bad Maine Beer Company beer? Poured into a pint glass from bottle. Good half inch head retention and a lovely deep amber colour. Pretty hoppy but beautifully deep and flavourful taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle date 3-24-14..pours a dark orange/light red color with a 1 finger head..good start here into MBC glass..nose is a combo of wet grass/dough.mouthfeel is light-medium bodied and has that fresh clean consistency that epitomizes their offerings..slight spiciness here that has some rye quality..also a lingering malt bill..a bit of spice..bit of sweet and just enough hop character to round everything out..whatever you want to categorize this as..doesnt matter it is another solid offering from MBC..bring on the 4 packs already..guys?
Bottle to glass...dated 3.25.14...so 19 days ago. Pours a foggy red with major 2 finger head. Sweet malty (rich) nose; lots of hops in the taste...bitter but very pleasant...tasty....

16.9 oz. bottle. Pours a sort of cloudy reddish amber, to the light side, with a 2 finger off white head. Little bit of lace. Wonderful hoppy aroma with a background of tropical fruit. A little bit of sweetness in the flavor with a solid backbone of biscuits and honey. Lots of fruit flavors too, tropical and citrus. Smooth bodied and easy to drink, this beauty was gone way to fast.
Aroma is yeast, malts, light tropical fruit and fruit/sugar. The flavor is malts, tropical fruit, light tea, very light hop resin notes, citrus and a long and tart/tangy/mildly bitter finish.

At my place with Taylor, Matt, and Jacob. Aroma is huge floral hops, light spice, some halt backbone. Taste is nice, nice big earthy hops, low bitterness, light caramel. Finish is kinda quick with a nice hope note.

Bottle. Pours red with white head that lingers. Radium hop grapefruit aroma over medium carbonation. Fruity hop flavor with burnt caramel. Very tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with the Danes. Pours a pretty reddish caramel color with good lacing. Aroma is nice tropical fruit, orange, toffee. Taste is burnt sugar, caramelized grapefruit, roasted pineapple, breakfast pastry, hint of coffee. Good, though I still prefer MO and MBCs other lighter beers.

Location/Date:Bottle on 4/8/2014.
Appearance: Pours a dark maroon with light head.
Aroma: Aroma of raisin, citrus.
Taste: Medium bitterness, orange, raisin.
Palate:Medium body, sticky.
Summary: When I bought this last week, thought I already had it - turns out I was wrong - a bonus. A nice amber style ale, well balanced per usual from Maine Brewing.

Bottle from Ayottes
Pours a stunningly clear red brown color with a huge fluffy milky white head that persists forever. Huge citrus hop aromas are nicely countered with a bit of caramel and toffee as well as hints of dark pitted fruits. The flavor is solidly malty with caramel and toffee up front with hints of dried fruits. Citrus earth and pine sweep in quickly to cut right through the fruity sweetness. Lingering hop bitterness last long after every sip. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a slick resinous mouthfeel. Another great beer from Maine beer. I would drink so much of this shit if I werent forced to buy it in 7 dollar pint bottles. Love your beer, hate your price point!

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a yellowish head. The aroma has notes of citrus fruits, hops, spices, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of citrusy hops, spices, malt, and a bit of alcohol, leading to a bitter finish.
Bottle - slightly fuzzy amber pour with good off-white head. Aroma and taste is fruity hoppy and malty, caramel, light toffee, butterscotch, fresh fruity, high drinkability for the abv, lovely stuff.

50 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small tan head. Aroma is peachy, grapefruity and mango. Passion fruity and mango hops flavoured. Crisp juicy hoppy. Bitter and lingering dry citrusy finish. Light pine note into the far finish.

Purchased at Charlestown Wine & Spirits RI 550ml bottle. This was especially foamy for me, it took a long time for the head to dissipate. I ate some of the foam and it was bitter. Once the off-white somewhat reddish head dissipated it revealed a cloudy dark, brownish red beer. The beer smells of hops and a metallic sweetness much like Ithaca cascazilla, just smells like red ale basically. Taste is pretty good and has this great, somewhat creamy body with light carbonation that is just perfect like Maines Lunch. Light and easily sessionable, has a decent hop presence but no lingering bitterness. Not ultimately too flavorful does has a good hop/malt balance but at the end of the day just taste like a regular red ale, moderately bitter and a metallic sweetness. Possibly the best Ive ever had of this style.

Poured from bottle from cellar at 55F. Pours a rich clear red-amber with ample off-white head. Initial aroma is hop (mostly citrus) and a touch of toffee and raisin. Taste is dominated by the hops, but there is a nice undercurrent of malty goodness to keep things in balance. Darn good and while Im drinking it by itself, I think it would go great with food.

Bottle. Clear dark copper with a big, foamy beige head that lasts and laces. Aromas of pine, grass, citrus, grapefruit, toasted malt and light orange. Flavor is pine, spice citrus, grapefruit, toasted malt, and light caramel. Medium bodied, bitter and slightly dry finish.

500ml bottle. Pours dark cloudy amber with a beautiful tan creamy head that sticks with lots of lacing. Taste is more hop bitterness than expected. Nice clove, tart apple, slight caramel, and cream taste. Very good balance. I am really liking the Maine Beer Co. offerings.

Bottle from WF Charlottesville. Deep hazy amber with a creamy off-white head. Robust caramel malts, marzipan, and toasted brown bread accented by fresh cut oranges and a touch of pine. Somewhat sprucy hop flavors, some cut grass. Dark fruit conserve and a bit more toast. Nice sweet/bitter balance, dry finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Overall, quite nice. This reminds me of fresh SN Celebration in a way.

Bottle purchased at whole foods in DC
pours deep amber hue with nice soapy off white head and nice lacing. nose is very hoppy-lots of grapefruit and floral notes with a nice caramel malt backbone. as the label says, this is not a red ipa, but its truely a hoppy amber ale. yes there is a difference. flavors of nice toated malt, caramel, lite bitterness, floral hop accents with a touch of citrus. one of the best hoppy ambers out there. not much of a finish-just lite lingering malt sweetness and some lite floral hops. excellent!

Large, rocky, tan, head with excelent retention and a thick coating lace. Murky, red hued brew. Well blended nose of caramel malts and C hops, sorta juicy, lil pissy. Med/full body, chewy, creamy. Fairly dry maltyness, caramel, pine and a hint resiny, almost luscious. Nice finish, good bitterness, slight dankyness, fair bite. Tasty critter. Bottle from statelineliquors. yummy, pricy.

500ml bottle in a teku. Pours deep amber with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of floral and citrusy hops plus caramel and cereal and some pale malts with light dough. Flavor the same with a decent blend of it all. Average texture. Not bad but not the best Maine beer.

Nice looking chestnut brown beer with a thick foamy light beige head. Pungent nose with some citrus, pine and light vinegar over a base of nuts. Flavor really builds on the aroma with a slightly sweet foundation that supports overtones of candle wax, almonds, and leather set off by a lingering bitterness with surprising acidity. Unusual beer with abundant complexity. The silky mouth feel with perky effervescence adds to the experience. Good beer--its like the bastard child of a brown ale and an IPA.

Last bottle from Wine Source. Pours dark amber, nice big white head, great lacing. Aroma is citrus hop, hints at malt undertones. Flavor is much like the mouthfeel: silky smooth-- caramel, hop infusion. Bittering towards the end, but the bit that sticks out is the velvety mouthfeel-- I can just imagine the millions of beer-bubbles as I quaff this again. Another great offering from MBC.

Bottle. Copper/ruby pour with a tall, fluffy tan head. Aroma is caramel, toasted malt, earthy hops, light floral notes and soft nuttiness. Taste is a touch hoppier with floral notes, caramel, toasted malt, light nuttiness and a touch of fruit. Body is medium with a creamy, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more nutty notes, toasted malt, caramel, light toffee, soft hops, floral notes and light fruity notes.

Bottle to glass. Pours a hazy amber color with a red hue and a creamy tan head. Aroma has piney, fleshy fruit, citrusy hops with a healthy caramel background. Flavor has much more malt character and a subdued piney hops. Light to medium in body with lingering malt and piney hops. Tasty indeed.

Bottle. Pours hazy reddish-brown with a mostly creamy head that thins to great lacing. Big aroma of sweet floral, ripe fruit, pine and citrus. Medium sweet and lightly bitter taste in a medium body. Creamy texture with soft carbonation that ends with a long finish in which the bitterness comes through in the far end.
Bottle at Jeffrey. Pours redish brown with big fluffy head. Nose if caramel malt. Tastes of caramel, red fruits, grapefruit, resin, earthy bitterness, other malt. Chewy texture and bitter finish.
From a 500 ml bottle a bit past its prime. Malty amber with big fruit tones.Caramel. Trace of what might have been hoppy.
Bottle from my special brother in chi-town, murky brown pour with light brown head, funky eww aroma but taste is freaking awesome.... taste is hopps, caramel, nice clean finish
Des biscuits à lorange et du sucre d orge comme base pour une ambrée hyper ronde et équilibrée. Buvabilité haute.

Bottle: &nbsp Dirty amber, somewhat thick, pillowy sandy head, nice lacing.&nbsp Nice sweet citrusy nose, caramel malts, bready, some minor hops. &nbsp Soft breadiness up front, a bit airy and overly carbonated. &nbsp Soft citrus peel, a little candied. &nbsp Not as heavy or rich as I thought based on the nose. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Citrusy finish, pith and peel, soft breadiness, airy, with a bit of toasted malts. &nbsp Decent Amber, but a bit too airy. &nbsp Dated 11/12/13.

Bottle pours with a clear lightly hazed deep copper body that supports a thin tan head. The aroma offers up a nice mix of roasted malts, malts, nuttiness and a bit of sweet molasses. The taste has a pleasing mix of rich roasted malts and maltiness along with complimentary modest pine hoppiness. This comes together nicely.
Bottle from CK. Beautiful amber pour with a lovely off white head. Nose holds spruce, pink grapefruit, lemongrass, hints of toffee and shortbread. Flavor much the same; gorgeous balance. Damn good.

They say that it is NOT a red IPA, but the hop character is fantastic and it comes off as one (which is fine by me). Reminds me a lot of Troegs Nugget Nectar. Color- deep reddish orange with fluffy off-white head. Flavors of pine, grapefruit, and apricot come through. Love it.

Another nice one from Maine BC. The label tells you everything you need to know before trying this one. I thought it might be a clone or brother to Zoe, but its not. The bready, cereal like malts are actually evident in this along with the hop punch that makes a really nice balanced beer.
Reddish pour with a nice lightly tinged white head. Chewing body with nice resinous hops, quality caramel malt notes and a hint of doughy malts.

Bottle at Andys for New Years Eve. Bit of a gusher. Pours a hazed orange amber with a medium sized beige head. Big earthy hops on the nose, malty sweetness. Medium-bodied, soft earthy malt and hops. Long grapefruit and quinine into the finish.

Murky red-amber with big, flotsam, beige head, good lacing / Nose of pine, soap, earth, citrus / Light to medium body, hoppy with lots of bitterness, not malty as description promises and thus a touch out of balance / Flavors of pine, dry hop, caramel, with notes of light citrus and dark fruit / Its is pretty much a red IPA.
From 50 cl bottle at Churchkey DC. Pours a clear amber with an ecru head. Fruity hop nose. Flavors of blood orange with a malty backbone. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Smooth bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours a light amber body with some minor white lacing. Aroma is fresh bitter hop up front, followed by a soft malt profile. Mouthfeel is medium and brightly carbonated. Flavor includes notes of fresh pine/grass hop, light toasty malt, mild bitterness and fresh grapefruit. A world class representation of the amber ale style.

Half liter bottle from Beer Run, opened 11/27/13. Excited to try another one from these guys. And the William Carlos Williams tribute is excellent. I too was an English major who was exposed to and developed an appreciation of WCW. Pours a hazy rust color with a large foamy tan head, about 4 fingers. Good head retention. Aroma of spicy, floral, earthy hops with mild caramel malts and some apricot-like fruitiness, also mild. The taste is bitter earthy, citrus, spicy hops, stone fruits and caramel malts. Medium bodied, low carbonation, very slight lingering bitterness, nice balance. Solid beer.
Bottle. Poured an amberish color with an off white head. Floral, fruity, and citrus. Tastes follow with some caramel.

Bottle. Pours a clear reddish amber body under a one finger frothy beige head that left lots of sticky lacing. The nose is fresh floral and fruity hops over a toasty and fairly dry malt base. The beer pours a caramel amber with a massive head of light, toffee-colored, creamy, mid-sized bubbles that last, leaving a ring of sticky, fat lacing on the sides of the glass. In body, the beer is clear and clean, but with a pronounced haze, perhaps from the heavy use of hops in the beer. On the nose, the beer smells richly of citrus grapefruit and prickly pine. The caramel malt is also nicely present, giving the nose caramel bread notes. Sweet citrus pith is dominant on the nose, however, and provides a nice aroma. The yeast character is clean and faint on the nose, and as the beer warms you do get a touch of hot alcohol on the nose, unfortunately. On the tongue, the beer tastes bitter and softly roasty, with a nice bready sweetness balancing out the sip. Mild citric acidity plays into the finish, where the beer dries out and gives the tongue a nice bitter click. In flavor, the beer begins as caramel roast, almost like a light ice coffee with toffee syrup. Citrus quickly swims onto the tongue, providing strong grapefruit flavors. The finish is like grapefruit juice with a touch of medicinal bitters and caramel bread, and the aftertaste is citric bitters and sweet toffee and bread. As the beer warms, the rich malt does appear more pronounced in the aftertaste, giving off warm oat bread flavors with a touch of caramel and toffee. In the mouth, the beer feels medium in body, almost light, but with a creamy carbonation and crisp mouthfeel that provide for a very interesting sip. There is a slight, resiny stickiness left in the mouth after the swallow. Overall, this is a more hop-forward amber ale, but it gives beautiful malt character as well. As the beer warms, more and more of the caramel bread can be sensed in the beer. The balance ends slightly on the bitter side, which will appease any hop heads, but the malt balance is also delicious. This beer is another success from the MBC, and honestly might give Zoe a run for her money. A side by side test will need to be administered.
